item.title: Pokemon GO Is Getting Another Mega Lucario Raid Day, But Not Everyone Can Take Part
item.description:
Highlights

  • A makeup day for the Mega Lucario Raid event will take place on July 28, with rewards including 5 Star Pieces and 5 Lucky Eggs.
  • Players affected by issues will get their Raid Passes back, but Niantic hasn't specified the regions for this rerun.
  • With a lack of info on who can participate, players will need to stay tuned for updates or check themselves to see if they can access the rerun on July 28.

Niantic has announced that it will be organizing a makeup event for Mega Lucario Raid Day on Sunday, August 27, due to some issues that were encountered by a few Pokemon GO players. Pokemon GO players will also be getting some rewards as part of the compensation, but Niantic has not announced exactly which regions will get the rerun.

While the previous Ultra Unlock event witnessed the arrival of Maushold in Pokemon GO , all eyes were on the Strength of Steel event. Fans have been eagerly waiting for the arrival of mega evolutions of Metagross and Lucario for years now, and they finally got the latter. Despite the hype around the event, it seems like it has had its fair share of issues.

In a new tweet, Niantic Support has announced compensation for players who were affected by issues during the Mega Lucario Raid Day in Pokemon GO . Apparently, some players were not able to get the Mega Lucario Raid Day ticket bonuses after 5 pm. This issue only affected players in certain time zones. To compensate for the problems faced by the players, Niantic is extending the Mega Lucario Raid Day as well as the ticket bonuses to Sunday, July 28, from 12 pm to 5 pm local time for only those players who were affected.

Pokemon GO Mega Lucario Raid Day Makeup Event Schedule & Rewards

  • Schedule - Sunday, July 28th from 12 pm to 5 pm local time
  • Rewards - 5 Star Pieces and 5 Lucky Eggs

Additionally, players will also be getting back the Raid Passes they used, and along with that, they will also get 5 Star Pieces and 5 Lucky Eggs in Pokemon GO . While all that might sound quite lucrative, the strange thing is that Niantic hasn't announced which time zones will be getting this makeup event. The fact that Niantic had to rerun the event suggests that quite a significant number of players were affected. However, Niantic keeping the specifics under wraps is something that has left fans perplexed.

This is not the only issue that players faced during the Mega Lucario Raid Day. In fact, some players reported that the Mega Energy awarded when walking with Lucario was also bugged in Pokemon GO . Instead of 25 Mega Energy, which is the norm for 5km buddy Pokemon, players were reportedly getting 15 Mega Energy. Whether Niantic addresses this issue as part of the upcoming event is something that remains to be seen.

item.title: Best Settlements For Endgame Builds In Fallout 4
item.description:
Highlights

  • Fallout 4 introduced settlement building, allowing players to create personalized, imaginative settlements in 37 different locations.
  • Some settlements, like Kingsport Lighthouse and Bunker Hill, offer unique and endgame-worthy bases for players to retire and build.
  • Players can unlock settlements like Echo Lake Lumber and Egret Tours Marina, offering visually stunning locations with plenty of build space.

Fallout 4 was released in 2015, bringing with it a fresh innovation in the Fallout franchise - settlement building. This mechanic went one step further than simply owning a hideout or renting a room by enabling a player to truly manipulate the environment, creating a personalized, imaginative settlement. It doesn't end with just one settlement, though - Fallout 4 contains no fewer than 37 settlements, from the relatively understated buildings to the simply enormous, open spaces.

For years, players have worked to construct the most inventive builds possible. With the added assistance of creativity-focused mods, some fantastic settlements have emerged from the Fallout 4 community since 2015. However, while there are dozens of possible settlements to claim in Fallout 4 , not all of them are worth it, and only a few among them can be considered "endgame bases." These are the locations where players can retire, build their final settlement, and finally hang up the Pip-Boy.

Updated on July 27, 2024, by Benjamin Joe: Fallout 4 was Bethesda's first Fallout game with settlement-building mechanics. Players can create bustling towns filled with people from all over the Commonwealth. There are lots of settlements that the player can unlock while exploring post-war Boston. From Sanctuary Hills to Echo Lake Lumber, there are lots of fantastic places to build cool creative settlements with the tools and talent made available to them through the Sole Survivor's exploration of the wasteland across Fallout 4 and its various DLCs.

17 Finch Farm

More Than Meets The Eye

  • A Low-Level Area
  • Build On Top Of A Freeway

Finch Farm is one of the locations that the player will likely come across early on during their playthrough. While it doesn't look like much at first glance, this area has the potential to be turned into a bustling town.

Above the outpost is a large freeway. It's possible to build on top of the road, making it the perfect place to build a settlement. The road above is long and flat, making it an easy place to build on. Also, it offers fantastic views of the surrounding areas.

16 Nuka-World Red Rocket

A Fun Place To Build in Nuka-World

  • Nuka-World's Only Settlement
  • Plenty of Build Space

If a player follows the story chronologically, the Nuka-World Red Rocket will be the last settlement they unlock. It's the only settlement found in Nuka-World , the final DLC released in the Fallout 4 lifecycle, which coincidentally serves as something of an endgame expansion. It pushes the player into a hostile theme park environment, overrun by raiders and all manner of mutated creatures.

Bizarrely, in the considerably vast and diverse map of Nuka-World, there is just one settlement - the Nuka-World Red Rocket. While it's not the most beautiful setting for an endgame build, it's an iconic brand in the Fallout universe, and it offers a relatively large, open build space.

15 Graygarden

Great For Harvesting Food

  • Inhabited By Robots
  • Plenty Of Food

Graygarden is one of Fallout 4's strangest settlements. It is run by a handful of helpful robots. The robots that call this place home may be a little odd, but they are surprisingly friendly. The area itself is located on a hillside. This helps to make spotting attackers pretty easy.

As for the build area, while there isn't a lot of free land to build on, players can incorporate the road above into their build. Also, one of the robots, Supervisor Brown, will purchase Mufruit from the player for 2 Caps each. While it's not much, since Mutfruit is easy to farm, players can make a decent chunk of change by simply harvesting the nearby Mutfruit.

14 Kingsport Lighthouse

A Cool Place To Build

  • Great Vantage Point
  • Picturesque Location

Kingsport Lighthouse was originally occupied by the Children of Atom, who are hilariously 'powering' the lighthouse by entrapping a Glowing One at the top of it. It's a unique location that boasts a large build area, but it's a great endgame settlement for the sheer diversity of what's on offer. Firstly, there's a large, central building, alongside which is a towering, complete lighthouse. At the back of the property is a mostly undamaged pier, which houses further, smaller buildings.

It's one of the best base canvases for a settlement, especially considering most of the buildings are undamaged. For players that want a unique retirement home, there's the option to build at the very top of the lighthouse, upon which the player can survey the wide, open world of the Commonwealth Wasteland.

13 Croup Manor

A Waterside Retreat

  • Easy To Defend
  • Great For Farming Water

Croup Manor is tucked away from most of the dangers of the Commonwealth. Located on a stretch of land on the eastern side of the map, this location is right on the water's edge, which helps to keep enemies away. While the manor itself is in pretty bad shape, the land around the manor is great for building a settlement that can house lots of settlers.

Since the settlement is surrounded on two sides by water, it is pretty easy to defend. A couple of well-armed settlers placed on guard posts should be enough to ward off any attackers.

12 Bunker Hill

An Interesting Late-Game Settlement

  • A Well-Fortified Settlement
  • Home To An Iconic Landmark

Bunker Hill is home to several notable NPCs. It's the place where traveling traders get some much-needed rest. It's surrounded by walls which help to keep attackers at bay, and it has a market in the main building where players can sell their wares.

While it can be a difficult place to build due to the many existing structures, a skilled builder can do quite a lot with Bunker Hill. The giant Bunker Hill Monument can be incorporated into the players' build to create a unique living space for all who choose to call Bunker Hill their home.

11 Echo Lake Lumber

A Far Harbor Town With A Cannibal Resident

  • A Cool Yet Creepy Aesthetic
  • A Somewhat Secluded Area

Echo Lake Lumber is one of four settlements that the player can obtain in Far Harbor. Like most of the locations in Far Harbor, Echo Lake Lumber gives players an unsettling feeling when roaming around this area. While the area is quite large, there are lots of pre-existing structures that can get in the way. But, if the player is an experienced builder, then these buildings shouldn't be much of an issue.

There are some interesting stories tied to this location. Players can also decide the fate of the settlers, as there's a creepy guy called Malcolm who has a taste for human flesh.

10 Egret Tours Marina

A Peaceful Spot For Those Who Want To Be On The River

  • Perfect For Farming Water
  • A Visually Stunning Area

Egret Tours Marina is probably the most visually inviting settlement that players can obtain. There are several pre-existing buildings that are in pretty good shape considering how long they have been left to rot. The marina itself is a great place to place a handful of Industrial Water Purifiers to make some extra caps.

There's quite a lot that can be done with this settlement to make it more welcoming to visitors. As far as Fallout 4 goes, players will be hard-pushed to find a more visually pleasing location.

9 Sunshine Tidings Co-Op

A Big Place With A Lot To Offer

  • Filled With Mostly Complete Cabins
  • Plenty Of Build Space

Located on the western side of the map, Sunshine Tidings Co-op is a nice farming settlement with lots of open space and sturdy cabins to build in. Before the war, this place was just a regular run of the mill farm. But now, with a little elbow grease and a few materials, this area can be turned into a countryside escape where settlers can go to feel safe.

There's a big barn in the center and a handful of buildings that circle the exterior perimeter of the building area. These buildings provide natural cover and shelter from potential threats. With a bit of creativity, this seemingly regular farm can be turned into a central hub for settlers and traders alike.

8 Longfellow's Cabin

A Home From Home

  • An Isolated Location
  • Plenty of Build Space

Found nestled in the fog-ridden island in Far Harbor, Longfellow's Cabin is a brilliant endgame settlement for one key reason: it's already an endgame settlement for someone else. When the player meets Longfellow, they're introduced to a surly yet helpful individual who has been leathered and wizened by decades in the wasteland. He decided to house himself away from the core settlements in Far Harbor, opting to get a little peace and quiet.

As a result of this move, Longfellow's Cabin is in an undisturbed area of the map, set in an area full of trees and perched atop a small cliff that boasts clear-ish views of the map. It's one of four settlements introduced in Far Harbor, and it makes a perfect location to build that ideal retirement property.

7 Abernathy Farm

The Tallest Build Height in The Game

  • Tallest Build Space In The Game
  • Lots Of Flat Lands To Build On

Abernathy Farm is one of the settlements that the player will encounter pretty quickly after leaving the vault. Built underneath a large power pylon, Abernathy Farm is home to the Abernathy family. After helping the family, the sole survivor will be able to take control of the settlement.

This particular settlement has the highest build limit in the game. Players can build structures that are up to 20 stories tall! Not only that, but the relatively flat terrain around the pylon makes it easy to build large structures without too much difficulty.

6 Starlight Drive-In

A Nice Open Space

  • Lots of Flat Land
  • A Fairly Large Build Limit

Starlight Drive-In is one of the settlements that players can get their hands on relatively early. It is a great end-game settlement due to how large and flat the terrain is. There's a large old-fashioned American diner on one side, a large parking space in the middle, and an old outdoor cinema screen on the other side. This place gives players the ability to build large and unique structures.

The diner and cinema screen are all within the buildable area , so the player can incorporate them into whatever idea they may have. As a whole, this area is perfect for building something big and bold that fits in with the local surroundings.

5 Home Plate

Build A Home in Diamond City

  • Surprisingly Large Build Limit
  • A Cozy Indoor Base

For the more social player, a perfect endgame settlement can be found in the heart of Diamond City. This is arguably the central location in Fallout 4 , coming equipped with several quest-givers, multiple stores and vendors, and being home to key story missions. For a fee, the player can purchase ownership of Home Plate, a relatively small building located in the Diamond City Market. It's not a huge location, and it's entirely enclosed (it's an interior-only settlement), but it feels cozy and can be packed out with furniture, thanks to the generous build limit.

It makes sense that a player would retire to this location, particularly if they're playing something of an RP game. Why should the Sole Survivor live outside in the wasteland, suffering from the post-apocalyptic conditions, when they can reside in the relative safety of Diamond City? It's the perfect endgame settlement for any budding Fallout 4 fan.

4 The Slog

A One-Of-A-Kind Place

  • Easy To Defend
  • Great Land For Farming

The Slog is an old spa and bathhouse. There's a pool outside that settlers use to grow Tarberries. There are lots of reasons why The Slog is a great place for end-game builds. It's in a low-level area, meaning that enemies are pretty easy to take care of. It is easy to fortify thanks to the large spa building next to the pool. And, it has lots of open space to plant crops and make a farm.

This picturesque place is perfect for some cool and unique builds. For example, players can build several levels over the swimming pool and turn the old spa into a modern spa clinic. Overall, there's a lot to love about The Slog. It is a fantastic place to settle down and build.

3 Sanctuary Hills

The Sole Survivor's Pre-War Home

  • The Player's First Home
  • A Fairly Safe Neighborhood

It ends where it all began, in Sanctuary Hills. This is the first location that the player is exposed to in Fallout 4 , serving as the home of the Sole Survivor. Following a few minutes in an idyllic, pre-war setting, the player emerges from a brief stint in a vault to find that the haven of Sanctuary Hills now stands devastated by 200-plus years of wasteland survival. It's now a relatively blank canvas; a ball of clay ready to be molded by the player.

Ultimately, Sanctuary Hills remains one of the best locations for an endgame build simply for the reason that the player is 'going home.' It's a massive, open space that boasts broad, flat areas and pre-built houses to fill with furniture. It's also set in an attractive part of the map, sitting on a river and surrounded by trees. There are worse places in Fallout 4 to build an endgame settlement, that's for sure.

2 Nordhagen Beach

Close Enough To Paradise

  • Stunning Views
  • Pretty Secluded

It is easy to overlook this place at the beginning. But there's a lot that can be done with this particular area. Aside from the road that runs through the outside, it's surrounded mostly by water, making it a fun place to build away from the dangers of the Commonwealth. It also has a nice view of The Prydwen, provided the player hasn't taken out the Brotherhood of Steel.

The nice coastal views and the ability to see a lot of Boston's large buildings from afar make this a great place to hunker down and call home for end-game players.

1 Vault 88

Own A Vault

  • Massive Build Area
  • Fun To Explore

Introduced in the Vault-Tec Workshop DLC, Vault 88 is the perfect retirement opportunity for players looking to retreat underground, living out the apocalypse in a vault. However, there's a twist, as this vault is a blank canvas; an enormous, sprawling cave with many subsections that can be used to build a massive, complex vault. It's able to be fitted with all the above-ground amenities that a player is used to, along with all the new features introduced in the Vault-Tec Workshop DLC.

Admittedly, Vault 88 is the toughest endgame settlement to build on, for the simple reason that the player is starting totally from scratch. It'll be quite a task to accomplish, with every tunnel, door, level, and room needing to be built from the ground up. However, when it's completed, the player is rewarded by having the ability to retire to an underground vault of their very own.

item.title: SpongeBob Isnt The Only Minecraft Crossover Mojang Should Revisit
item.description:
The SpongeBob SquarePants add-on for Minecraft will receive an expansive update on August 20. First released in 2022, the new update will have players venture back to a blocky version of Bikini Bottom and be able to complete various quests such as jellyfish-catching and searching for Gary the Snail. Each quest completed will unlock blueprints for iconic undersea buildings for players to create with new blocks and furniture, including the busy Krusty Krab restaurant and Sandy Cheeks air-filled Treedome. While fans of the over 25-year-long Nickelodeon series may be excited about exploring Minecraft under the sea with this update, Mojang should consider revisiting and updating other crossovers with famous franchises.

Minecrafts Mash-Up Crossover Packs Explained

For years, players have been able to mod and add new mobs, items, and textures to Minecraft to create new and exciting experiences in their blocky world. However, these were just fan-made creations and were rarely supported by Mojang itself. It wasnt until 2013 that Mojang would begin releasing mash-up packs so that players' worlds could officially be changed to mirror some players favorite games, shows, movies, and more. Changes to the world often vary, but the mash-up packs typically add new textures, skins, music, and new loading screens when purchased and downloaded. Mash-up packs textures can additionally be used on other worlds beyond the packs template world.

Minecraft s first mash-up pack released in late summer 2013 on home consoles in the form of the Mass Effect Mash-up Pack. Based heavily on the early Mars mission seen in 2012s Mass Effect 3 , the Mass Effect Mash-up Pack changed the texture for every block and item to reflect the futuristic technology of the 22nd century. As players explore Mars, listening to Mass Effect s iconic soundtrack, they can change their skin to play as up to 36 characters across the Mass Effect series. However, mobs didnt have their texture changed, unlike future mash-up packs such as the Halo and Greek Mythology mash-up packs.

While the Minecraft SpongeBob SquarePants add-on wont be updated till late August, players can currently claim the Spongebob -inspired Imaginaaaation Character Creator headwear item for free from the Dressing Room.

Minecraft Crossovers in Need of an Update

Minecraft mash-up packs have received occasional updates, but these were primarily limited to new textures made for new items and mobs or skins to reflect new entries in a series, such as the Infinite Master Chief skin in the Halo Mash-up Pack. Mojang could update a few mash-up packs beyond these limitations to add more structures and quests to better mirror new or popular entries. Two mash-ups in particular that could use a facelift are the Fallout and Skyrim Mash-up packs.

The Fallout Mash-up Pack was released in 2016 and was based primarily on 2015s Fallout 4 and 2008s Fallout 3 with recreations of the Prydwen aircraft and the town of Megaton to name a few. With the recent success of Amazon Primes Fallout series and the tease of the second season taking place in New Vegas, Mojang should expand the template world and add locations from Fallout: New Vegas and the Fallout TV show. Some of the new locations could be the New Vegas Strip and the NCR capital Shady Sands. There are enough locations in both entities that Mojang could make an entirely new mash-up world which could include new items and textures such as armor based on NCR veteran rangers.

An Expanded Elder Scrolls Mash-Up Pack

The Skyrim Mash-up Pack was released in 2013 and featured only a few locations from 2011s The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim , such as the city of Whiterun and the Nordic ruin Bleak Falls Barrow. While Elder Scrolls games are large enough to fill multiple mash-up template worlds on their own, Mojang could expand it to feature iconic locations from The Elder Scrolls 4: Oblivion and The Elder Scrolls Online . Some of these locations could be the towering Imperial City or the Summerset Isles, while the Nether could be turned into the Daedric realm of Oblivion, with the Nether portals themselves designed to better resemble Oblivion Gates.

item.title: 8 Best Co-Op Roguelikes On The Nintendo Switch
item.description:
Highlights

  • The Switch is a prime spot for co-op Roguelikes, offering diverse gameplay options for groups of gamers to enjoy together.
  • Games like Risk of Rain 2 and For The King provide challenging and rewarding experiences, perfect for long co-op sessions.
  • Whether you prefer deck-building adventures or chaotic bullet hell shooters, the Switch has a variety of Roguelikes to suit your gaming needs.

Roguelikes are some of the most replayable games available, and sometimes, gamers want nothing more than to get together with a friend or three and try their luck playing run after run of their favorite Roguelike, whether they win, lose, or just try out some crazy new combos, builds, and strategies.

The Nintendo Switch has quickly become a favorite home for Roguelikes and co-op games alike, and developers have taken note. Whether a group of gamers want to play something with fast-paced runs that almost always end in sadness, or they want to spend hours on a single run just to scrape out a victory, the Switch has plenty of options to choose from!

8 Across The Obelisk

Slay The Spire Meets Dungeons And Dragons

Across The Obelisk is a deck-building Roguelike that lets players form a four-person party made up of many unique and fun classes. Every class feels unique and has plenty of depth and builds to try out.

Across The Obelisk is one of the most fun co-op games on Steam and on the Nintendo Switch, but its card-based gameplay lends itself very nicely to handheld mode on the Switch.

7 For The King

A Turn Based RPG Perfect For Long Sessions

For The King lets up to three players work together in classic RPG form. Players each choose their class andteam up, moving through a polygon tile-based overworld to defeat monsters, clear dungeons, and complete quests while leveling up their characters and gear.

Unlike many other awesome Roguelikes, For The King actually has a four-player sequel, but it has yet to make its way to the Nintendo Switch. Still, For The King sessions offer hours of pure Roguelike RPG entertainment.

6 Don't Starve Together

A Punishing Survival Roguelike

Don't Starve Together is a very strange (in a good way) twist on the classic Roguelike formula. It's a survival game at heart, but a survival game where death is permanent if players aren't prepared, and all players dying can end a run, especially early on.

Don't Starve Together is one of the best co-op horror games on the Nintendo Switch. The art is enthralling and creep,y and most groups need to experience loss quite a few times before they finally get the hang of the game. The long runs, however, make every failure worthwhile.

5 Risk Of Rain 2

A Chaotic Action-Packed Third-Person Shooter

Risk of Rain 2 is a fast-paced third-person shooter Roguelike that does a fantastic job fusing the two genres together. There are many characters for players to experiment with, and every run feels winable, especially when players can infinitely stack power ups and basically break the game if they're lucky.

Risk of Rain 2 plays extremely well on the Nintendo Switch, and playing with friends is one of the most enjoyable and chaotic experiences that Roguelike fans can find in gaming.

4 Barony

A Very Difficult Roguelike With Lots Of Class-Race Combos

Barony is perfect for groups that want to play a very punishing first-person Roguelike with a lot of depth and builds available. Barony lets players experiment with a ton of different race and class combos, so they can be a skeleton monk, goblin warrior, vampire healer, or anything else they want!

While the difficulty can be off-putting, certain sections of the Roguelike fandom will immediately fall in love with Barony, and the gameplay and graphics fit right at home on the Nintendo Switch!

3 Streets Of Rogue

Grand Theft Auto Meets Roguelikes

Streets of Rogue is one of the most unique Roguelikes available on the Nintendo Switch, or any other system, due to its incredible emergent gameplay and variety of playstyles. For example, if a player needs a key, they can take it by force, befriend the owner of the key, leak toxic gas through vents and take the key, or do anything else their imagination can come up with.

Streets of Rogue can be played basically forever with a group of friends because co-op mode just adds more brains and more hands to the problem, and the solutions available quickly become jaw-dropping!

2 Enter The Gungeon

Co-Op Bullet Hell With Tons Of Guns

Enter the Gungeon is absolutely perfect for Roguelike players who want to play a bullet hell shooter. Enter the Gungeon also has adorable graphics, and uses the classic isometric perspective that Roguelike fans have fallen in love with.

The graphics and gameplay of Enter The Gungeon fit right at home on the Nintendo Switch. There are a ton of different guns to try out in, and the game is very difficult, even with a friend, making it a great Roguelike for long, rage-fueled co-op sessions.

1 The Binding Of Isaac: Afterbirth+

Massive Replayability And Variety

The Binding of Isaac is one of the most prominent modern games to popularize Roguelikes and Roguelike mechanics. It is an icon and an inspiration among its peers, and has truly set the bar for all of its successors.

The Binding Of Isaac plays extremely well on the Nintendo Switch since it is a twin stick shooter, and playing with a friend is fun and chaotic. It's a game that can be easily picked up and played by anyone!

item.title: Marvel Rivals Setting Change is a Must for Venom Mains
item.description:
Highlights

  • As pointed out by Twitch streamer Flats, disabling the Easy Swing seting makes for smoother Venom gameplay in Marvel Rivals.
  • Venom, a sturdy Vanguard in Marvel Rivals, disrupts enemy attacks with swing and regen abilities, but with Easy Swing on, it can be hard to control where he is going.

A Marvel Rivals player has shared a useful tip that will make the gameplay for Venom mains much smoother. Marvel Rivals started its closed beta on July 23, giving players another chance to test the upcoming shooter after the closed alpha held in May.

With this new test underway, Marvel Rivals players can play PvP 6v6 third-person matches on maps based on Yggsgard and Tokyo 2099, two iconic locations in the Marvel universe. The Convoy, Domination, and Convergence modes are available, as are a selection of playable characters such as Iron Man, Punisher, Scarlet Witch, Hela, and Black Panther. Increasing the hype for the Marvel Rivals beta even further, NetEase revealed the debuts of Adam Warlock and Venom, with Thor and Jeff the Land Shark also joining the game recently. For players looking to dominate the battlefield with the famous Symbiote, a Marvel Rivals tip will significantly improve their Venom gameplay.

Twitch streamer flats_ow showed on his TikTok how disabling the Easy Swing option greatly changes Venom's gameplay in Marvel Rivals . In the video, he reveals that disabling Easy Swing gives players more fluid and precise swinging while controlling the iconic Marvel Symbiote during matches. The reason is that when Easy Swing is off, the Marvel Rivals character will move to any point the player's reticle is pointed at. When it's on, the game will automatically select the nearest grappling points.

Venom is one of the Marvel Rivals' Sturdy Heroes

Marvel Rivals has three roles, with Venom corresponding to the Vanguards. Like the tanks in Overwatch 2 , the Vanguards lead the team on the front line, protecting their teammates while still having the ability to dish out decent damage. Venom, in particular, is considered a solid pick for Marvel Rivals players due to the Symbiote's potential to disrupt the enemy team's attack. Venom can also last longer on the battlefield due to his swinging and regeneration abilities.

The Marvel Rivals beta ends on August 5, and players who didn't get a code can try to get one through a friend, or via Marvel Rivals' Twitch Drops. Players who join the closed beta will have the chance to get a special Venom skin that will remain unlocked when the game fully release. Fans of tank roles will be able to try out Hulk, Doctor Strange, Groot, Magneto, and Peni Parker, the other characters who make up Marvel Rivals ' Vanguard category.
